page.title: Charles de Beauvau, Prince of Beauvau

revision.comment: [[Help:Cat-a-lot|Cat-a-lot]]: Copying from [[Category:French Senators of the Second Empire]] to [[Category:19th-century French politicians]]
revision.text:
'''Charles Juste François Victurnien, de Beauvau, Prince of Craon''' (1793–1864) was a 19th-century [[French people|French]] senator and army officer. He was styled the Prince of Beauvau.
Charles was born on 7 March 1793 at [[Sunninghill, Berkshire|Sunninghill]] in [[Berkshire]], while his parents, [[Marc Étienne Gabriel of Beauvau-Craon|Marc Étienne Gabriel]], [[Princes of Beauvau-Craon|Prince of Beauvau-Craon]] and Nathalie Henriette Victurnienne de Montemart, were in exile in [[England]] from the [[French revolution]].
After the family returned to [[France]], he entered the [[French army]] in 1810, during the [[Napoleonic Wars]], becoming an officer of [[carabinier]]s, two years later, during the [[French invasion of Russia|campaign]] against [[Russia]]. He was nominated [[Senate (France)|senator]], and elected Councillor-General of the [[Meurthe Department|Meurthe]] in 1854.
== References == {{reflist}} * Martin, Frédérick (1870), ''Handbook of Contemporary Biography''
